Award.AwardTitle: Louis Stokes Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jackson State University, lead institution for the Louis Stokes Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation (LS-MAMP) will continue to make a significant contribution to the nation?s science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through the statewide alliance. The LS-MAMP is a consortium of six (6) state supported universities (Alcorn State University, Jackson State University, University of Mississippi, Mississippi State University, University of Southern Mississippi, Mississippi Valley State University), one private college (Tougaloo College); and a community college (Hinds Community College).
The partnership will continue to implement and improve recruitment and retention strategies through community college bridge programs, synergistic scientific leadership development programs, global internship research programs, business, industrial and governmental (BIG) STEM internship programs, outreach programs, institutionalization programs, and other programs that will contribute to LS-MAMP?s systemic shared transformative (SST) vision. The vision is to produce and increase the competitiveness and number of globally astute STEM graduates from historically underrepresented minority (URM) populations in the state and nation who are prepared to make a positive impact in graduate school and/or the workforce.
Through the LS-MAMP program, the number of highly competent, competitive, globally astute URM STEM graduates who are prepared to make a positive impact in graduate school and/or the workforce within Mississippi and the nation will be increased. Furthermore, through the LS-MAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) program, alliance institutions will increase the number of STEM doctoral degrees to historically underrepresented minorities who will become well-qualified scientists, STEM faculty members, mathematicians, and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Louis Stokes Mississippi Alliance for Minority participation-(LMAMP is a historic statewide consortium of eight (8) colleges and universities of higher learning. - Alcorn State University (ASU), Jackson State University (JSU), Mississippi Valley State University (MVSU)), and one private college (Tougaloo College (TC)); and three Comprehensive Research Universities - University of Mississippi (UM), Mississippi State University (MSU), and University of Southern Mississippi (USM), and a community college (Hinds Community College (HCC)).  LS-MAMP was one of the first six alliances funded by NSF to address the underrepresentation of minority students in STEM. Mississippi’s universities and colleges have a strong history of cooperation characterized by individual institutional strengths combined with collective sharing of resources to provide opportunities for addressing the state’s science and technology needs in a spirit of collaboration.  The Mississippi Alliance committed to this shared mission and persist in our endeavors to improve minority student outcomes across the state of Mississippi and the nation.  Approximately 40.3% of Mississippi’s population is minority with African Americans accounting for 98% of this demographic.  These numbers justify the push for attracting and preparing minorities for STEM careers, (US Census Bureau, 2016).   

 Accomplishments and Outcomes

 The under-preparedness of Mississippi students has rendered a large portion of the URM population as being unprepared for STEM college programs. Despite URM students’ enthusiasm for and knowledge of the importance of a STEM education, many high school graduates do not pursue a STEM major as they have not acquired or been exposed to the tools necessary for success in these disciplines.  LS-MAMP has been instrumental in developing pathways for successful student transition to STEM majors and has aided in changing this pattern for a significant number of URM students in the region. By providing GRE classes, enrichment activities, Speakers, conferences, and tutors to students opportunity of graduate.

Throughout the decades of its implementation, the LS-MAMP enrollment of URM STEM students increased by an average of 2 % per year as compared to the 1.1% for nonminority STEM students. Similarly, the number of URM BS graduates increased by 6 % annually as compared to 3 % for nonminority students. The marked achievements of the Alliance were deeply rooted in the cooperation and collaboration within and among the alliance sites. The LSAMP institutions in Mississippi have varied campus environments where students represent diverse geographic and socioeconomic backgrounds. Given this variation, the Alliance has succeeded in minimizing these differences by focusing on a shared vision, implementing best practices interventions, and leveraging local resources to increase enrollment, retention and graduation of URM STEM students.

   During the last five years, LS-MAMP has continued to create a strong pipeline of well-prepared STEM BS graduates who have joined the workforce or continued their education toward STEM research careers. A major factor contributing to increased enrollment for several Alliance institutions has been the growth in transfer STEM students from community college partners to the four-year intuitions. In the same period, the enrollment of URM STEM at the four-year institutions increased nearly 21 percent .  The participating four-year institutions have contributed an annual average of more than 700 STEM Baccalaureate to the STEM workforce and research career pipeline in the state during this five-year period. The Alliance has not only met its target to grow URM STEM graduates to 25 % but rather has realized an increase of 29% in the number of URM STEM graduates
